issue.title: Data segment overlaps
issue.body:
[Data segments](https://github.com/WebAssembly/design/blob/master/BinaryEncoding.md#data-section) aren't well defined.

* If they overlap, does it fail?
* If so, what's the exception?
* When is it thrown? Some of these issues can be known at Module time (if it was an `i32.const`), and others at Instance time (if it was a global).
* If they're out of bounds, does it fail?

comment.body: This is fun. What if the memory exists but is zero-sized, and we initialize with an empty data segment?

comment.body: Another one: what if there's an empty data section, and no memory (neither imported, nor memory section)? Is that an error at Module creation time?

issue.title: Add length field for the init_expr
issue.body: `init_expr` is defined as "normal encoding of the expression followed by the end opcode as a delimiter." It will be hard for naive scanner/parser to skip the this field without fully parsing the expression -- we cannot just scan till the `end` code since a constant might have this byte/code. Will it be better to add the length field similar to the function body?

comment.body: @wllang the burden is on you to do these things. I'll be delighted if you confirm such opportunities.

comment.body: @jfbastien So you don't know if a decoder would be simpler and faster without local variables? Surely some people here who have implemented decoders would know, and couldn't you confirm with someone on your team. After confirming these advantages, it would appear that the only remaining question is the encoding efficiency, and why hasn't your team or other teams got these results on what is a clear performance improvement and simplification? Who are you expecting to do the design work and when did you expect to reach a MVP, or are you going to push a MVP out with such low hanging fruit unexplored?

issue.title: Explain validation and checking after branches
issue.body:
Validation is currently only defined in the spec, which is not approachable by everybody. This PR describes the basic idea.

Based on various online and offline discussions it also makes the handling of unreachable code more precise, trying to address a couple of concerns that keep coming up with the status quo, namely:

1. it allows implementations to diverge to some degree, by not requiring them to fully check,
2. it is not easy to understand for everybody what that lenience implies,
3. non-lenient validators need a certain amount of inference, especially with potential future feature like `dup`.

The description in this PR makes the treatment of code after branches precise (removing any lenience) and tries to adopt the simplest possible rules. For most implementations, it should not imply any real change. The spec interpreter and the test suite would need some adjustment (removing the "soft failure" mode).

comment.body: One other thing I forgot to mention: having implemented the more general version of this PR in SM (unreachable-mode continues out of blocks), we can confirm it is a source of impl bugs in practice, particularly when some code that has been given validated-wasm forgets about the special cases introduced by unreachable-mode.

issue.title: Explain validation and checking after branches
issue.body:
Validation is currently only defined in the spec, which is not approachable by everybody. This PR describes the basic idea.

Based on various online and offline discussions it also makes the handling of unreachable code more precise, trying to address a couple of concerns that keep coming up with the status quo, namely:

1. it allows implementations to diverge to some degree, by not requiring them to fully check,
2. it is not easy to understand for everybody what that lenience implies,
3. non-lenient validators need a certain amount of inference, especially with potential future feature like `dup`.

The description in this PR makes the treatment of code after branches precise (removing any lenience) and tries to adopt the simplest possible rules. For most implementations, it should not imply any real change. The spec interpreter and the test suite would need some adjustment (removing the "soft failure" mode).

comment.body:
Definitely agreed on the goals of precisely defining validation so that spec/ref-interp/engines can all precisely match, and not making significant changes (e.g., that would require a new binary version).

While this PR does avoid the major problems of the currently-spec'd polymorphic validation, it seems unfortunate to add a whole cross-cutting mode (in both the spec and all impls) just to handle the special case of instructions between an unconditional block and the following `end`/`else`, particularly because practically all wasm used in production will have no such instructions.

The alternative I prefer would be to introduce no such mode and simply reject any instructions between an unconditional branch and the following `end`/`else`.  This option:
* is the most conservative, and could be loosened later
* should accept practically all wasm output today
* does not prohibit unreachable code
* requires simple syntax-directed compilers to either use a flag that inhibits codegen (set when emitting an unconditional branch and unset when the block is closed) or to wrap unconditional branches in `block`/`end`

The only downside I'm aware of is that syntax-directed compilers would have to do the above instead of ignoring the issue entirely.  Given that the syntax-directed compiler's choices are simple and that optimal syntax-directed translation is not thus far a high-level goal, I think that this is the right tradeoff.  I'd be interested to hear what others think about this tradeoff.

Either way, though, I agree we need to nail this down so we're validating the exact same thing.  [I'm afraid I'll be on PTO for the next week so sorry in advance for the week delay in response.]

issue.title: Data segment overlaps
issue.body:
[Data segments](https://github.com/WebAssembly/design/blob/master/BinaryEncoding.md#data-section) aren't well defined.

* If they overlap, does it fail?
* If so, what's the exception?
* When is it thrown? Some of these issues can be known at Module time (if it was an `i32.const`), and others at Instance time (if it was a global).
* If they're out of bounds, does it fail?

comment.body:
Oh and if initializing segments fails halfway, I assume it's visible up to when it failed? i.e. if the first segment is valid but the second isn't, then the first is set, second isn't?

And what if a segment is only partly valid? i.e. it starts in range but ends out of range. Do we see a partial write, or none of that segment's write? I'd rather not do partial, but that's what wasm does when executing.

issue.title: Add length field for the init_expr
issue.body: `init_expr` is defined as "normal encoding of the expression followed by the end opcode as a delimiter." It will be hard for naive scanner/parser to skip the this field without fully parsing the expression -- we cannot just scan till the `end` code since a constant might have this byte/code. Will it be better to add the length field similar to the function body?

comment.body: @jfbastien Great a thumbs down, but can you justify it in technical terms? I don't yet know if wasm without locals is a better place, but have good reason to suspect it will be compelling, it certainly simplifies decoding to validated SSA, and it certainly helps the reader, and I see good reason why it will help a simple compiler, but I will get the remaining answers. But do you know? If not then why give it a thumbs down?

pull_request.body:

issue.body: `init_expr` is defined as "normal encoding of the expression followed by the end opcode as a delimiter." It will be hard for naive scanner/parser to skip the this field without fully parsing the expression -- we cannot just scan till the `end` code since a constant might have this byte/code. Will it be better to add the length field similar to the function body?

comment.body: @jfbastien Great a thumbs down, but can you justify it in technical terms? I don't yet know if wasm without locals is a better place, but have good reason to suspect it will be compelling, it certainly simplifies decoding to validated SSA, and it certainly helps the reader, and I see good reason why it will help a simple compiler, but I will get the remaining answers. But do you know? If not then why give it a thumbs down?

issue.title: Explain validation and checking after branches
issue.body:
Validation is currently only defined in the spec, which is not approachable by everybody. This PR describes the basic idea.

Based on various online and offline discussions it also makes the handling of unreachable code more precise, trying to address a couple of concerns that keep coming up with the status quo, namely:

1. it allows implementations to diverge to some degree, by not requiring them to fully check,
2. it is not easy to understand for everybody what that lenience implies,
3. non-lenient validators need a certain amount of inference, especially with potential future feature like `dup`.

The description in this PR makes the treatment of code after branches precise (removing any lenience) and tries to adopt the simplest possible rules. For most implementations, it should not imply any real change. The spec interpreter and the test suite would need some adjustment (removing the "soft failure" mode).

comment.body: One other thing I forgot to mention: having implemented the more general version of this PR in SM (unreachable-mode continues out of blocks), we can confirm it is a source of impl bugs in practice, particularly when some code that has been given validated-wasm forgets about the special cases introduced by unreachable-mode.

issue.title: Explain validation and checking after branches
issue.body:
Validation is currently only defined in the spec, which is not approachable by everybody. This PR describes the basic idea.

Based on various online and offline discussions it also makes the handling of unreachable code more precise, trying to address a couple of concerns that keep coming up with the status quo, namely:

1. it allows implementations to diverge to some degree, by not requiring them to fully check,
2. it is not easy to understand for everybody what that lenience implies,
3. non-lenient validators need a certain amount of inference, especially with potential future feature like `dup`.

The description in this PR makes the treatment of code after branches precise (removing any lenience) and tries to adopt the simplest possible rules. For most implementations, it should not imply any real change. The spec interpreter and the test suite would need some adjustment (removing the "soft failure" mode).

comment.body:
Definitely agreed on the goals of precisely defining validation so that spec/ref-interp/engines can all precisely match, and not making significant changes (e.g., that would require a new binary version).

While this PR does avoid the major problems of the currently-spec'd polymorphic validation, it seems unfortunate to add a whole cross-cutting mode (in both the spec and all impls) just to handle the special case of instructions between an unconditional block and the following `end`/`else`, particularly because practically all wasm used in production will have no such instructions.

The alternative I prefer would be to introduce no such mode and simply reject any instructions between an unconditional branch and the following `end`/`else`.  This option:
* is the most conservative, and could be loosened later
* should accept practically all wasm output today
* does not prohibit unreachable code
* requires simple syntax-directed compilers to either use a flag that inhibits codegen (set when emitting an unconditional branch and unset when the block is closed) or to wrap unconditional branches in `block`/`end`

The only downside I'm aware of is that syntax-directed compilers would have to do the above instead of ignoring the issue entirely.  Given that the syntax-directed compiler's choices are simple and that optimal syntax-directed translation is not thus far a high-level goal, I think that this is the right tradeoff.  I'd be interested to hear what others think about this tradeoff.

Either way, though, I agree we need to nail this down so we're validating the exact same thing.  [I'm afraid I'll be on PTO for the next week so sorry in advance for the week delay in response.]

issue.title: Explain validation and checking after branches
issue.body:
Validation is currently only defined in the spec, which is not approachable by everybody. This PR describes the basic idea.

Based on various online and offline discussions it also makes the handling of unreachable code more precise, trying to address a couple of concerns that keep coming up with the status quo, namely:

1. it allows implementations to diverge to some degree, by not requiring them to fully check,
2. it is not easy to understand for everybody what that lenience implies,
3. non-lenient validators need a certain amount of inference, especially with potential future feature like `dup`.

The description in this PR makes the treatment of code after branches precise (removing any lenience) and tries to adopt the simplest possible rules. For most implementations, it should not imply any real change. The spec interpreter and the test suite would need some adjustment (removing the "soft failure" mode).

comment.body:
Definitely agreed on the goals of precisely defining validation so that spec/ref-interp/engines can all precisely match, and not making significant changes (e.g., that would require a new binary version).

While this PR does avoid the major problems of the currently-spec'd polymorphic validation, it seems unfortunate to add a whole cross-cutting mode (in both the spec and all impls) just to handle the special case of instructions between an unconditional block and the following `end`/`else`, particularly because practically all wasm used in production will have no such instructions.

The alternative I prefer would be to introduce no such mode and simply reject any instructions between an unconditional branch and the following `end`/`else`.  This option:
* is the most conservative, and could be loosened later
* should accept practically all wasm output today
* does not prohibit unreachable code
* requires simple syntax-directed compilers to either use a flag that inhibits codegen (set when emitting an unconditional branch and unset when the block is closed) or to wrap unconditional branches in `block`/`end`

The only downside I'm aware of is that syntax-directed compilers would have to do the above instead of ignoring the issue entirely.  Given that the syntax-directed compiler's choices are simple and that optimal syntax-directed translation is not thus far a high-level goal, I think that this is the right tradeoff.  I'd be interested to hear what others think about this tradeoff.

Either way, though, I agree we need to nail this down so we're validating the exact same thing.  [I'm afraid I'll be on PTO for the next week so sorry in advance for the week delay in response.]

issue.title: Data segment overlaps
issue.body:
[Data segments](https://github.com/WebAssembly/design/blob/master/BinaryEncoding.md#data-section) aren't well defined.

* If they overlap, does it fail?
* If so, what's the exception?
* When is it thrown? Some of these issues can be known at Module time (if it was an `i32.const`), and others at Instance time (if it was a global).
* If they're out of bounds, does it fail?

comment.body:
Oh and if initializing segments fails halfway, I assume it's visible up to when it failed? i.e. if the first segment is valid but the second isn't, then the first is set, second isn't?

And what if a segment is only partly valid? i.e. it starts in range but ends out of range. Do we see a partial write, or none of that segment's write? I'd rather not do partial, but that's what wasm does when executing.

issue.title: Add length field for the init_expr
issue.body: `init_expr` is defined as "normal encoding of the expression followed by the end opcode as a delimiter." It will be hard for naive scanner/parser to skip the this field without fully parsing the expression -- we cannot just scan till the `end` code since a constant might have this byte/code. Will it be better to add the length field similar to the function body?

comment.body: @jfbastien Great a thumbs down, but can you justify it in technical terms? I don't yet know if wasm without locals is a better place, but have good reason to suspect it will be compelling, it certainly simplifies decoding to validated SSA, and it certainly helps the reader, and I see good reason why it will help a simple compiler, but I will get the remaining answers. But do you know? If not then why give it a thumbs down?

comment.body: Oh, and if linking fails, is an imported memory changed by data segments? Or do data segments get populated after link succeeds, but before start is called?

pull_request.title: Update testsuite
pull_request.body:
* Non-imported globals can not be used in initializer expressions
* block/loop/if labels can be repeated at the end
* get_global index in initializer expression should reference use module
  index space, not "defined" global index space

Surely some people here who have implemented decoders would know, and couldn't you confirm with someone on your team. Who are you expecting to do the design work and when did you expect to reach a MVP, or are you going to push a MVP out with such low hanging fruit unexplored?

issue.body: `init_expr` is defined as "normal encoding of the expression followed by the end opcode as a delimiter." It will be hard for naive scanner/parser to skip the this field without fully parsing the expression -- we cannot just scan till the `end` code since a constant might have this byte/code. Will it be better to add the length field similar to the function body?

comment.body: @wllang the burden is on you to do these things. I'll be delighted if you confirm such opportunities.

issue.title: Add length field for the init_expr
issue.body: `init_expr` is defined as "normal encoding of the expression followed by the end opcode as a delimiter." It will be hard for naive scanner/parser to skip the this field without fully parsing the expression -- we cannot just scan till the `end` code since a constant might have this byte/code. Will it be better to add the length field similar to the function body?

comment.body: @jfbastien So you don't know if a decoder would be simpler and faster without local variables? Surely some people here who have implemented decoders would know, and couldn't you confirm with someone on your team. After confirming these advantages, it would appear that the only remaining question is the encoding efficiency, and why hasn't your team or other teams got these results on what is a clear performance improvement and simplification? Who are you expecting to do the design work and when did you expect to reach a MVP, or are you going to push a MVP out with such low hanging fruit unexplored?

comment.body: @wllang I simply disagree with removing locals without data backing up your assertions.

issue.title: Explain validation and checking after branches
issue.body:
Validation is currently only defined in the spec, which is not approachable by everybody. This PR describes the basic idea.

Based on various online and offline discussions it also makes the handling of unreachable code more precise, trying to address a couple of concerns that keep coming up with the status quo, namely:

1. it allows implementations to diverge to some degree, by not requiring them to fully check,
2. it is not easy to understand for everybody what that lenience implies,
3. non-lenient validators need a certain amount of inference, especially with potential future feature like `dup`.

The description in this PR makes the treatment of code after branches precise (removing any lenience) and tries to adopt the simplest possible rules. For most implementations, it should not imply any real change. The spec interpreter and the test suite would need some adjustment (removing the "soft failure" mode).

comment.body: One other thing I forgot to mention: having implemented the more general version of this PR in SM (unreachable-mode continues out of blocks), we can confirm it is a source of impl bugs in practice, particularly when some code that has been given validated-wasm forgets about the special cases introduced by unreachable-mode.

issue.title: Explain validation and checking after branches
issue.body:
Validation is currently only defined in the spec, which is not approachable by everybody. This PR describes the basic idea.

Based on various online and offline discussions it also makes the handling of unreachable code more precise, trying to address a couple of concerns that keep coming up with the status quo, namely:

1. it allows implementations to diverge to some degree, by not requiring them to fully check,
2. it is not easy to understand for everybody what that lenience implies,
3. non-lenient validators need a certain amount of inference, especially with potential future feature like `dup`.

The description in this PR makes the treatment of code after branches precise (removing any lenience) and tries to adopt the simplest possible rules. For most implementations, it should not imply any real change. The spec interpreter and the test suite would need some adjustment (removing the "soft failure" mode).

comment.body:
Definitely agreed on the goals of precisely defining validation so that spec/ref-interp/engines can all precisely match, and not making significant changes (e.g., that would require a new binary version).

While this PR does avoid the major problems of the currently-spec'd polymorphic validation, it seems unfortunate to add a whole cross-cutting mode (in both the spec and all impls) just to handle the special case of instructions between an unconditional block and the following `end`/`else`, particularly because practically all wasm used in production will have no such instructions.

The alternative I prefer would be to introduce no such mode and simply reject any instructions between an unconditional branch and the following `end`/`else`.  This option:
* is the most conservative, and could be loosened later
* should accept practically all wasm output today
* does not prohibit unreachable code
* requires simple syntax-directed compilers to either use a flag that inhibits codegen (set when emitting an unconditional branch and unset when the block is closed) or to wrap unconditional branches in `block`/`end`

The only downside I'm aware of is that syntax-directed compilers would have to do the above instead of ignoring the issue entirely.  Given that the syntax-directed compiler's choices are simple and that optimal syntax-directed translation is not thus far a high-level goal, I think that this is the right tradeoff.  I'd be interested to hear what others think about this tradeoff.

Either way, though, I agree we need to nail this down so we're validating the exact same thing.  [I'm afraid I'll be on PTO for the next week so sorry in advance for the week delay in response.]

issue.title: Data segment overlaps
issue.body:
[Data segments](https://github.com/WebAssembly/design/blob/master/BinaryEncoding.md#data-section) aren't well defined.

* If they overlap, does it fail?
* If so, what's the exception?
* When is it thrown? Some of these issues can be known at Module time (if it was an `i32.const`), and others at Instance time (if it was a global).
* If they're out of bounds, does it fail?

comment.body:
Oh and if initializing segments fails halfway, I assume it's visible up to when it failed? i.e. if the first segment is valid but the second isn't, then the first is set, second isn't?

And what if a segment is only partly valid? i.e. it starts in range but ends out of range. Do we see a partial write, or none of that segment's write? I'd rather not do partial, but that's what wasm does when executing.

issue.title: Add length field for the init_expr
issue.body: `init_expr` is defined as "normal encoding of the expression followed by the end opcode as a delimiter." It will be hard for naive scanner/parser to skip the this field without fully parsing the expression -- we cannot just scan till the `end` code since a constant might have this byte/code. Will it be better to add the length field similar to the function body?

comment.body: @jfbastien Great a thumbs down, but can you justify it in technical terms? I don't yet know if wasm without locals is a better place, but have good reason to suspect it will be compelling, it certainly simplifies decoding to validated SSA, and it certainly helps the reader, and I see good reason why it will help a simple compiler, but I will get the remaining answers. But do you know? If not then why give it a thumbs down?

comment.body: Oh, and if linking fails, is an imported memory changed by data segments? Or do data segments get populated after link succeeds, but before start is called?

pull_request.title: Update testsuite
pull_request.body:
* Non-imported globals can not be used in initializer expressions
* block/loop/if labels can be repeated at the end
* get_global index in initializer expression should reference use module
  index space, not "defined" global index space

issue.title: Data segment overlaps
issue.body:
[Data segments](https://github.com/WebAssembly/design/blob/master/BinaryEncoding.md#data-section) aren't well defined.

* If they overlap, does it fail?
* If so, what's the exception?
* When is it thrown? Some of these issues can be known at Module time (if it was an `i32.const`), and others at Instance time (if it was a global).
* If they're out of bounds, does it fail?

comment.body: This is fun. What if the memory exists but is zero-sized, and we initialize with an empty data segment?

issue.title: Add length field for the init_expr
issue.body: `init_expr` is defined as "normal encoding of the expression followed by the end opcode as a delimiter." It will be hard for naive scanner/parser to skip the this field without fully parsing the expression -- we cannot just scan till the `end` code since a constant might have this byte/code. Will it be better to add the length field similar to the function body?

comment.body: @wllang the burden is on you to do these things. I'll be delighted if you confirm such opportunities.

issue.title: Explain validation and checking after branches
issue.body:
Validation is currently only defined in the spec, which is not approachable by everybody. This PR describes the basic idea.

Based on various online and offline discussions it also makes the handling of unreachable code more precise, trying to address a couple of concerns that keep coming up with the status quo, namely:

1. it allows implementations to diverge to some degree, by not requiring them to fully check,
2. it is not easy to understand for everybody what that lenience implies,
3. non-lenient validators need a certain amount of inference, especially with potential future feature like `dup`.

The description in this PR makes the treatment of code after branches precise (removing any lenience) and tries to adopt the simplest possible rules. For most implementations, it should not imply any real change. The spec interpreter and the test suite would need some adjustment (removing the "soft failure" mode).

comment.body: One other thing I forgot to mention: having implemented the more general version of this PR in SM (unreachable-mode continues out of blocks), we can confirm it is a source of impl bugs in practice, particularly when some code that has been given validated-wasm forgets about the special cases introduced by unreachable-mode.

issue.title: Explain validation and checking after branches
issue.body:
Validation is currently only defined in the spec, which is not approachable by everybody. This PR describes the basic idea.

Based on various online and offline discussions it also makes the handling of unreachable code more precise, trying to address a couple of concerns that keep coming up with the status quo, namely:

1. it allows implementations to diverge to some degree, by not requiring them to fully check,
2. it is not easy to understand for everybody what that lenience implies,
3. non-lenient validators need a certain amount of inference, especially with potential future feature like `dup`.

The description in this PR makes the treatment of code after branches precise (removing any lenience) and tries to adopt the simplest possible rules. For most implementations, it should not imply any real change. The spec interpreter and the test suite would need some adjustment (removing the "soft failure" mode).

comment.body:
Definitely agreed on the goals of precisely defining validation so that spec/ref-interp/engines can all precisely match, and not making significant changes (e.g., that would require a new binary version).

While this PR does avoid the major problems of the currently-spec'd polymorphic validation, it seems unfortunate to add a whole cross-cutting mode (in both the spec and all impls) just to handle the special case of instructions between an unconditional block and the following `end`/`else`, particularly because practically all wasm used in production will have no such instructions.

The alternative I prefer would be to introduce no such mode and simply reject any instructions between an unconditional branch and the following `end`/`else`.  This option:
* is the most conservative, and could be loosened later
* should accept practically all wasm output today
* does not prohibit unreachable code
* requires simple syntax-directed compilers to either use a flag that inhibits codegen (set when emitting an unconditional branch and unset when the block is closed) or to wrap unconditional branches in `block`/`end`

The only downside I'm aware of is that syntax-directed compilers would have to do the above instead of ignoring the issue entirely.  Given that the syntax-directed compiler's choices are simple and that optimal syntax-directed translation is not thus far a high-level goal, I think that this is the right tradeoff.  I'd be interested to hear what others think about this tradeoff.

Either way, though, I agree we need to nail this down so we're validating the exact same thing.  [I'm afraid I'll be on PTO for the next week so sorry in advance for the week delay in response.]

issue.body:
[Data segments](https://github.com/WebAssembly/design/blob/master/BinaryEncoding.md#data-section) aren't well defined.

* If they overlap, does it fail?
* If so, what's the exception?
* When is it thrown? Some of these issues can be known at Module time (if it was an `i32.const`), and others at Instance time (if it was a global).
* If they're out of bounds, does it fail?

comment.body:
Oh and if initializing segments fails halfway, I assume it's visible up to when it failed? i.e. if the first segment is valid but the second isn't, then the first is set, second isn't?

And what if a segment is only partly valid? i.e. it starts in range but ends out of range. Do we see a partial write, or none of that segment's write? I'd rather not do partial, but that's what wasm does when executing.

comment.body: @jfbastien Great a thumbs down, but can you justify it in technical terms? I don't yet know if wasm without locals is a better place, but have good reason to suspect it will be compelling, it certainly simplifies decoding to validated SSA, and it certainly helps the reader, and I see good reason why it will help a simple compiler, but I will get the remaining answers. But do you know? If not then why give it a thumbs down?
